author: Saloni Dhruv
title: 10 ancient architectural wonders of India
text: Yahoo India Lifestyle • 28 February 2017 The mystic and the magic of India is what attracts most people towards it. Infact, India is one such country which never ceases to amaze and shock people with it’s culturally outlandish past. With the Indus Valley civilization and several subsequent empires and kingdoms, India is one of the world’s archaeological gems. There have been cultures that flourished due to the endless conquest of the regions between various empires and kingdoms. And these cultures have all brought different technological and architectural advances. India’s rich past is not just in the history textbooks. So experience the beauty of some of the most stunning archaeological wonders that our country has to offer. All images are sourced from Wikimedia Commons The landscape of Hampi, in Karnataka, is replete with the flows of Tungabhadra River. Amongst these picturesque settings lie a group of monuments that bear a living testament to the grandeur of the last empire of India – the Vijayanagara Empire. The Virupaksha Temple is one of the most popular structures at Hampi and was built in a typical Dravidian style by the Chalukyas who ruled the region around the 7th century AD. (Picture taken by Prathik for Wikimedia Commons ) Situated in Patan, Gujarat, Rani Ki Vav is an ancient step-well, that was built by Rani Udaymati in 11th Century AD, to worship hallowed waters of Saraswati River. An exquisite example of subterranean architecture, Rani ki Vav is 64 meters long, 20 meters wide and 27 meters deep. All of these storeys are carved with more 500 sculptures all of which represent humans, nymphs, gods and the kings in varying forms of skill, grandeur and intricacy, with the central theme being the ten incarnations of Lord Vishnu. (Picture taken by Bgag for Wikimedia Commons ) Built in the form of chariot of the Sun God, with twelve pairs of exquisitely stone-carved wheels drawn by seven horses, the Sun temple is a masterpiece of art. The temple has an elaborate and intricate mammoth structure that depicts the chariot of the Sun God replete with 24 carved wheels, each of them 3 m in diameter, pulled by seven horses and guarded by two lions at the entrance that bravely crush elephants. (Picture taken by Tetrakys for Wikimedia Commons ) The beautiful Chola temples represented the vast empire that Cholas established in Thanjavur. These magnificent temples built during the reign of Rajaraja were the epitome of the vast religious inclination of these rulers. This temple in the ancient time was note a mere religious center but a full functional business establishment which was served and maintained by a permanent staff of several hundred priests, 400 devadasi and 57 musicians. (Picture taken by Supraja Kannan for Wikimedia Commons ) Khajurao is famous all over the world as monuments that are an ode to sensuality. The temple complex represents union of another form too, that of Jainism and Hinduism. While the exact date of its inception is hard to assess, it appears in records dating as far back as 1335 AD, which describe it as a group of 85 temples. Falling into ruins, wars and natural hazards, only 22 out of these remain today. The temple complex has three distinct types of carvings, the cult icons, the Apsaras (beautiful maidens) and demi gods that are supposed to guard the temple. (Picture taken by Abhishekolay for Wikimedia Commons ) One of the most ancient educational centers in India, the university of Nalanda is located in Bihar and housed several learning centers, activity centers and a library so vast that it is said to have burned for three months after setting fire to it. After invaders destroyed and ransacked this Buddhist center of learning, only ruins of Nalanda University is left, which gives a testimony of how advanced and well-structured our ancient education system was. (Picture taken by Mrityunjay Nalanda for Wikimedia Commons )
